sub_topic: Calculating the molar mass of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the molar mass of Calcium Carbonate (CaCO₃)? Show your calculations.
message_2:
To calculate the molar mass of Calcium Carbonate (CaCO₃), we need to find the molar mass of each element present in the compound and then add them together.

Calcium (Ca): 1 atom × 40.08 g/mol (molar mass of Ca) = 40.08 g/mol
Carbon (C): 1 atom × 12.01 g/mol (molar mass of C) = 12.01 g/mol
Oxygen (O): 3 atoms × 16.00 g/mol (molar mass of O) = 48.00 g/mol

Now, add the molar masses of each element together:

Molar mass of CaCO₃ = 40.08 g/mol (Ca) + 12.01 g/mol (C) + 48.00 g/mol (O) = 100.09 g/mol

So, the molar mass of Calcium Carbonate (CaCO₃) is 100.09 g/mol.
